title: Ralf Little reveals letter sent to Jimmy Savile asking to be like Rolf Harris
text:
A young Ralf was completely unaware of the horrors his heroes would later be convicted of (Picture: Metro.co.uk)

Death In Paradise’s Ralf Little has uncovered an innocent childhood letter that really aged badly – asking Jimmy Savile to fix it for him to draw more like Rolf Harris.

At the tender age of just seven years old, young Ralf was completely unaware of the horrors that would be revealed decades later, and just wanted to learn how to draw.

So, he decided to write in to family favourite show Jim’ll Fix It in an attempt to try and get some help from Rolf Harris, another of his heroes.

In the letter, which contained scattered pictures attempting to draw cartoon classics including Bugs Bunny, Fred Flinstone and Yosemite Sam from Looney Tunes, Rolf wrote: ‘Dear Jim, I would like to draw cartoon characters like Rolf Harris because I am very interested in drawing cartoon characters.’

He signed it Ralf Little, aged seven, as well as his address in the hope that his TV icon would get back in touch with him and grant him his wish.

Posting the photo of Twitter, Ralf wrote: ‘Bearing in mind “Jim” is of course “Saville” this letter has not aged well.’

Ralf Little wanted to draw like his hero as a child (Picture: Twitter/Ralf Little)

You can say that again. Considering both Savile and Harris have since been convicted of a series of sexual offences, many of which are involving children underage or in their care at the time of the incidents.

In both cases, it took decades for victims to come forward with tales of their abuse suffered at the hands of the two men.

Following Savile’s death in 2011, more than 450 alleged victims aged five to 75 reported incidents of historic abuse to the Metropolitan police.

Ralf is replacing Ardal O’Hanlon on fan fave Death in Paradise (Picture: BBC)

For some cases, the abuse was alleged to have occurred in NHS hospitals, of which Savile was a fundraiser.

Rolf Harris was convicted of 12 counts of indecent assault in June 2014, for crimes that took place between 1968 and 1986.

These included one offence against an eight year old fan, two children in their early teens, and years’ worth of abuse against a friend of his daughter.

He was sentenced to five years in prison in 2014, and was released on licence in May 2017 after serving three years.

In May 2017, he was accused and cleared of four more historical sex offences, and in the same year, one of the 12 convictions against him, which involved an eight year old girl in 1969, was overturned after an appeal.
